raw_comment: From the graph, I noticed that legacy applicants have a significantly higher admissions rate across the board (over twice the average rate). However, those wither higher parental income had a proportionally larger benefit: up to 7 times the average for the top 0.1%, compared to less than triple (already high) for non-legacy. This leaves several burning questions: among them, why are admissions so heavily skewed in favor of high-income, legacy applicants, and what steps can colleges take to reduce this (likely-systematic) bias?
ace_sentences: I noticed a fact from the graph.
Legacy applicants have a significantly higher admissions rate across the board.
The admissions rate of legacy applicants is more than twice the average admissions rate.
Applicants with higher parental income have a larger benefit.
The top 0.1% income group has an admissions rate that is up to 7 times the average admissions rate.
Non-legacy applicants have an admissions rate that is less than 3 times the average admissions rate.
Admissions are heavily skewed in favor of high-income legacy applicants.
I ask why admissions are heavily skewed in favor of high-income legacy applicants.
I ask what steps colleges can take to reduce this bias.
